etymology.description: Duplication of 辛: two chisels/knives marking prisoners, indicating recrimination/accusation; quarrel; debate.
etymology.interpretation: Doubling 辛 suggests two opposing instruments of punishment, evoking mutual accusation and contention. Pairing identical tools implies back-and-forth disputation and the act of distinguishing sides.

parts.english: bitter; punishment; chisel; eighth heavenly stem

examples.chinese: 两人因旧怨辡不休(兩人因舊怨辡不休)。
examples.pinyin: Liǎng rén yīn jiùyuàn biàn bù xiū.
examples.english: The two kept quarrelling over an old grudge.

examples.chinese: 史书记载他们在廷中辡是非(史書記載他們在廷中辡是非)。
examples.pinyin: Shǐshū jìzǎi tāmen zài tíng zhōng biàn shìfēi.
examples.english: Historical records note they disputed right and wrong in court.

examples.chinese: 在训诂中，辡也指区分、辨别的过程(在訓詁中，辡也指區分、辨別的過程)。
examples.pinyin: Zài xùngǔ zhōng, biàn yě zhǐ qūfēn, biànbié de guòchéng.
examples.english: In philology, biàn also refers to the process of distinguishing and discerning.
